def kill(self, .. skip_errors=None):

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: All, please let me know if you agree with the approach and what else I should be adding.  I can resolve any test issues as needed.

As others have noted, this is not the correct way to approach this. The -1 is for that. The APIs we have allow you to select the type of key generated, not the algorithm used to generate the keys.

I think there are three ways I can see to do this:

1. Add a new parameter to the 'POST /os-keypairs' API that allows you to specify the algorithm used:

    POST /os-keypairs
    {
      "name": "test-key",
      "type": "ssh",
      "algorithm": "ecdsa"
    }

2. Add a config knob to allow the operator determine what type of SSH keys are issued.

3. Change the default type returned (with or without API microversion) with no configuration option

Option 1 appear to be the most correct approach initially, since the API would continue to behave identically across all clouds. However, that's a lot of work for something that an end-user would likely never care about (all SSH keys are kindofalmostsorta equal). Option 2 is arguably config-driven API behavior but the API is still returning SSH keys and afaict we never stated the algorithm used in keys returned by this API (the algorithm information is visible in the generated key). It's also much easier and backportable (downstream anyway). I'd rule out option 3 since it's the worst of both worlds.

Based on discussions in #irc, it was decided that the best approach here is to simply create the relevant key in tempest itself - as is done here --

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/807465

I'm waiting for that review to merge, and then I will abandon this patch.

I agree, as this is API change please add a spec for that in nova-specs repo

- https://review.opendev.org/q/project:openstack/nova-specs

The linter is likely going to complain about the stray whitespace in the test_keypairs.py file. I'm good with this. The generators could be a little more DRY, but since one accepts a bitlength and the other doesn't, it's likely to result in more code instead of less.

this is an api change and requires a spec

I have a few questions:
1. This tools seems to be more of a orchestration tool that can be used to update the 3 certificates in DC by utilizing a new ICA (which is good). What happens if a system already has custom certificates installed? The existing certificates will be replaced (instead of migrated into cert-manager), correct? (This means we probably need to document that this tool can't be used if there are custom certs installed and user want to keep using them). 
2. Looks like the tool installs the ICA cert as the ssl_ca cert. But implementations based on openssl (python urllib3 for example) will verify a full cert chain, from the leaf to the very root CA. In this case, the client side needs to trust the root CA instead of the ICA, meaning the root CA (instead of the ICA) needs to be installed as ssl_ca. 

(I know docker is ok by trusting only the ICA, have you tested oidc? I believe eventually we want to install the root CA anyway.)

Please take another look folks, if you haven't yet.
I have addressed all comments. Let me know if there is anything else of concern.

Thank you.

1 - Correct Andy. They will be replaced. I can document it warning users that this is actually a replace so that they are fully aware. Thanks for pointing it out.

2 - Yes Andy, both registry local and oidc-auth work with new certificates based on the ICA. They do not require the Root CA to be installed as well. Tested with docker login to registry.local and registry.central and oidc-auth for oidc-auth-apps.

For my second question, since we install the ICA CA cert for access from within the cluster (and they don't require fully cert chain verification), I think it's ok. For client accessing from external, it should trust the root CA (instead of the ICA).
Marking as WIP while I test the playbook with these changes

I think I have addressed all the comments.
Please take another look.
Thanks

@Greg Waines @jerry Sun Don't we need to install the root CA that signed the ICA used in the playbook as "ssl_ca" on the system? If i understand correctly, when we use oidc-auth-apps cert for oidc app, the kube-apiserver has to pick up the root CA that signed this, isn't it? and also for docker_registry cert, when we change this on subclouds using this playbook, the root CA has to be installed on subclouds to access the systemcontroller's central registry. Please clarify

Contributing to this:

Andy asked the same in 01/12/2021 and I replied to it on 02/12/2021.

docker.central:

It does not need the root CA to be installed.
I have tested it with:
'docker login registry.central' from subclouds, after installing new certificates.

oidc-auth-apps:

It does need the root CA for inside-cluster communication.
I have tested it by reapply the app and have pods restarting and connecting without issues. 

Also I have tested by using 'oidc-auth -c 10.31.1.3 -u pvtest1 -p Li69nux*' and checking that a new entry for pvtest1 user is added to /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf

For external communication, it might need the root CA as Andy pointed out. I would appreciate if someone can help me with that test.

If the target does not exists or is not online, ansible will already inform that the host is unreachable so I think this is fine. 

Now, for checks regarding patches and update, what are the best places or commands to check that?
I think the check for management affecting alarms should suffice. I would double check with Greg/John.

Considering that this playbook can target standalone system as well as system controllers and subclouds, I would like to come up a simple solution that works everywhere.

Having that said, there are many patch and upgrade related alarms. I would like to suggest that besides checking for patches/updates we expand this and check for 'no alarms'. The default behavior would be that the playbook only runs in a system with 'no alarms' present. That would allow us to tackle patches/upgrades but also other important system events as well, like k8s upversion, k8s root ca update or even a system with low memory or CPU.

Checking for alarms would also allow for a simple solution, just one place to check instead of many.

Additionally, we can add a new extra-var to allow users to bypass this behavior after a careful analysis of the alarm in case.
May want to use "free" strategy as opposed to the default linear strategy.

One alternative is to make "project_id" changes possible via manila-manage. However, there are a couple of disadvantages here. 

since "manila-manage" directly interfaces with the database, there is no possibility of performing contextual validations such as: "does the user belong to the right project", "are the source/destination projects valid", etc. We can't perform RBAC checks or tally quotas, and can't get the destination project's buy-in for transfers. Also, manila-manage tooling is available only to privileged users. The proposed approach allows transfers to be a tenant user driven activity.

thanks for remind me there's another way,but this doesn't sound very different from directly tampering with a database, As you mentioned, there are many disadvantages to this direct modification, so don't use it as alternatives.

The intent of this alternatives section is to call out everything that's possible and to highlight the disadvantages. So i'd encourage adding both of these and call out the specific disadvantages so that reviewers/users will understand why this feature is required...
please add that this API will return a transfer ID and auth key - the auth key cannot be retrieved later on.

What actions will this API perform?

Will it update the "user_id" field in the resource?

The API will perform the following actions:
1: check RBAC policy.
2: get salt from db by transfer id.
3: to calculate crypt_hash with salt and auth_key by sha1.
4: Compare the calculated crypt_hash with the database crypt_hash.
5: check quota of destination project.
6: if share has snapshot or replica, then check corresponding quota
7: manila api----> manila share ----> driver: self.driver.accept_transfer()
8: db api perform transfer_accept: update status(awaiting-transfer-->available), user_id(source_user_id----> dest_user_id), project_id(source_project_id---> dest_project_id)
then update corresponding share snapshot and replica infomation.

so the "user_id" field will be update.

This has a huge security impact. You must note that:

1) each of these transfer APIs will be protected by RBAC
2) Users can only transfer shares belonging to their project
3) The transfer ID and transfer auth key  are expected to be conveyed out of band. The transfer auth key is only returned by the API during creation of a transfer. There will be no way to retrieve the transfer auth key after a transfer has been created. 
4) the choice of cryptographic algorithms to generate an auth_key and the fact that transfer IDs are non-guessable UUIDs will provide additional security to the process.
5) Since transfers expire in an hour, there's a time bound protection to this critical change of namespaces.
We must notify to external listeners when a volume transfer has been initiated and when it has been accepted

Looking at the HTML document [1], the JSON requests and responses are being rendered with grave accents before the first curly bracket and after the last. I suggest using the code-block directive [2] with the JSON lexer [3] to fix that. The only example I could find in the Manila-related repositories was this one. [4]

[1] https://ae655092bbb5b4f5ee61-b3e81020c9d0d64d224068ffd33ef104.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/818854/5/check/openstack-tox-docs/3016106/docs-html.tar.gz

[3] https://pygments.org/docs/lexers/?highlight=json#pygments.lexers.data.JsonLexer
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/branch/master/manila/api/v2/share_snapshots.py#L90

Almost! The .. code-block:: string is being put inside the code block along with the JSON object. I believe you should remove one colon from the Request Example:: and Response Example:: lines. When you put two colons in fron of a string, Docutils thinks it's a directive.

I think this shouldn't be a problem, but I'd align the start of the JSON object with the letter 'c' of code-blocks, just to be sure it renders properly.

it turns out that OVN is lacking the ablity to model that a port is moving form one host to anohter.
so you cannot correctly tell ovn to install flows on the dest without it removing them form the souce today.

as a result there will alwasy be packet lost (includign the RARP frames) whcn using ovn until

to that end we want to repoen the idea of merging this workaround upstream while we follow up with libvirt to add a public interface to trigger the self announce.

the other change we likely will make is move the binding profile activation to the start of post_live_migrate to also make that happen as early in that callback as possibel. it wont help much but i might help if you have a lot of cinder volumes i can adress that in a followup patch.

I'm trying to understand what you're saying here.  

The purpose of this function is to either import or generate a key pair in nova.

If you just want to import a key pair, then you would imply pass in a public_key in kwargs and it will be uploaded to nova.  This part will continue to work exactly the same with ecdsa keys ie. the new code is only triggered if public_key not in kwargs.

If you want to generate a keypair, though, then for rsa keys, we simply pass a POST to nova, and nova will generate an RSA key and return the public and private keys, which we pass back to the caller.

The problem right now though is that nova does not currently support generating ecdsa keys.  We need to add support for that in nova (and I can put a patch up for that), but until that happens, we need to generate the ECDSA key here, upload the public key to nova, and return the public and private keys exactly as nova would have done.

So I agree that we shouldn't be doing this here ultimately - we should do this in nova - but can we do this here temporarily until the needed change merges in nova?  (And I should probably document this in the doc string above)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: As far as I can tell, this code looks correct

As a followup to the issues I raised in my comment...I think as a workaround we could document that for BMC images for the N3000 the admin user should use the md5sum of the device image file as the bitstream ID.  That would ensure that different files get different IDs and the same file gets the same ID.

I think there are some logic bugs in the code as written, but they should be fairly straightforward to resolve.

More worryingly, in the rehoming case we currently have no 100% reliable way to check based on sysinv DB contents whether a device image on a rehomed subcloud is the same device image as in the new system controller.  In particular, the bitstream ID we specify for a BMC image is basically meaningless and we don't store the bmc_build_version/bmc_fw_version/retimer_A_version/retimer_B_version fields in the DeviceImage database table.   So as it stands for BMC images we're totally dependent on the admin user manually entering in the same bitstream ID for the same device image on the old system controller and the new system controller.

We're also totally dependent on the admin user not re-using the same bitstream ID for multiple BMC images since there's no uniqueness constraint.

We could query the hardware to see its current status (as this commit currently does), but that doesn't actually help us since we don't have any way to map that against what BMC versions the device images are supposed to provide (since the sysinv DB doesn't contain the bmc_build_version/bmc_fw_version/retimer_A_version/retimer_B_version fields in the DeviceImage database table).

Code change seems fine.
Need Chris to approve before increasing the vote.
I think we need to tweak the logic slightly.
Changes make sense to me.  Chris should also re-review.

distributedcloud/dcmanager/audit/firmwar.message: I expect you'll probably also need "bmc" and "retimer_included".

For the N3000 there are actually three separate types of functional images.  User images, bmc images, and bmc images with retimer firmware.  The bitstream ID only applies to the user image.  The other two are indicated by the "bmc" and "retimer_included" fields in the DeviceImage.

You might need to consult with Teresa about how to check whether a given bmc image has been applied to a device.  I think we'd have to check the bmc_build_version/bmc_fw_version/retimer_a_version/retimer_b_version values in the PCIDevice class.
Just to make things interesting, it sounds like the DeviceImage object doesn't actually know what BMC version or retimer version a BMC image would provide.

I think this might be logically checking the wrong thing.  The original code is checking whether a device image would be applicable to write to a given PCI device, based on any option device labels specified on the image.

Then later on at lines 197 we check to see whether the image was successfully written to the device.

Neither of these things require the checks in _check_device_attr_match_image_type() where you are trying to compare the image with what is reported by the hardware scan.

The old code is looking at the device_image_state_obj (which specifies the status of a particular image being written to a specific device on a specific host) and is comparing the image UUID in the subcloud against the image UUID in the system controller.

This comparison of UUIDs is invalid in the rehoming case, instead we need to look up the image in the subcloud and compare the attributes of the image in the subcloud against the attributes of the image in the systemcontroller.

The comparison of image uuid is problematic once the subcloud is rehomed as one value is fetched from system controller whereas the other is fetched from subcloud. Hence, this check has been removed.

However, the comparison of device uuid is valid as both the values are picked up from the subcloud itself (primary key-foreign key in DB). This would not be affected by rehoming and would be kept as it is.

I have also modified the logic to make sure we fetch the image from the subcloud and then compare individual attributes with the system controller image.

If you look at the sysinv DB code, the DeviceImageFunctional class contains three items, bitstream_id, bmc, and retimer_included.  All three of them need to match for a BITSTREAM_TYPE_FUNCTIONAL image to match.

horizon/tables/actions.py.message:
I investigated the error in detail. The error happens when a base class does not have "base_options" attribute. For such case, it leads to:

  attrs['base_options'] = attrs

This casuse a circulated reference and sphinx hits the error.

I agree that the proposed code works, but I think it is better to change L.55 to

 options = dict(attrs)

It is a bit cleaer than doing it at last. L.55 is the only case where "options" dict is not a separate dict object than "attrs" passed as an argument of __new__.
For other cases (L.53 and L.69) "options" dict is newly created, so I think it is better to ensure "options" is a new dict when prepared at L.55 too.

The original Debian's release use a "rt" feature to build extra kernel

nit: This should be outside of the try block
Just wondering why do we check if the items are the same. Perhaps we can just always set the value regardless if it has changed?

The Transaction.commit() code for updates should only only send out a transaction if something really changes: https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/46d44cf3be0dbf4a44cebea3b279b3d16a326796/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L1777

So in this case we'd locally have a transaction, we'd call commit(), and then it would return with status UNCHANGED.

It's also a little new to update an a row locally and directly set it as the result. Usually result is set either in a readonly command, or we set the temporary uuid on an inserted row, and then *after we get the notification and reply from the server that it has been committed*, we use the row built from that notification.

In this case, we are actually setting the result to a row with changes that have not *necessarily* not been committed by the DB as the result. Though for the most part, code that used it would still be after we'd gotten the reply from the server since we block on commit(), and if there was an error we'd pass that along. So I think it *should* be safe to do.
Right, in any case, this operation should return the register UUID, not the register itself. I'll change it.

With current ovsdbapp AddCommand code, returning a RowView or Row works and doesn't call get_insert_uuid() which in this case should return None and lookup a Row and by the uuid and return a RowView. So I think either way should work

You are right. But I'm not sure how the transaction will handle this cache element. If there is no change, will this library force a DB transaction to update the value? Maybe this is a question for Terry.

I'm having trouble wrapping my head around this. If the external_ids in the Command are a subset of a particular row, we say we match? So if you create the Command with just one external id and that external id is in the row, then we return that it is a match--no matter what that external_id is?

We can add as many external_ids as we need. In Neutron in particular we are using one single ID. Depending on if the qos is for a port or a FIP, we set port:port_id or fip:fip_id

If we then call again this method with the same external_id (or just the specific port:port_id or fip:fip_id), we'll try to match it. Same as in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ovsdbapp/+/822138/9/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#453
I don't know if that actually replies to your question... Does it?

Ok now I understand. From the IRC conversation:

<otherwiseguy> ralonsoh: It just seems weird that literally any external id matching would cause it to match. I could imagine there being multiple external_id fields in existing rows that are non-unique, so the new code would just go through and update potentially 100s of matching rules just because some client had something like {'field_metadata': 'value'} in it or something. 
<otherwiseguy> When this Command is about adding a single item.


That means we can have repeated external_ids key:value pairs, that something acceptable. Of course, I'm just considering the Neutron specific case. I'll push a patch to explicitly define the key:value to be matched in external_ids, not only reading the external_ids passed.
So if the external ids are the same, regardless of 'direction', 'priority' and 'match', they're considered the same qos rule?

Exactly, this is now a "create or update" method.

If we pass a "external_id", this will be considered first always, regardless of the tuple (direction, priority, match). Of course, if you don't pass these values, the mentioned tuple will be tested.

I believe the idea is that if a specific external_id key ,which is defined to mark this rule as unique, matches, then match it and potentially update it. It essentially turns QosAddCommand to QosAddOrUpdateCommand.

All other permissions are correct, only "watch" is missing.
It could be a regression as I found an old BZ mentioning the same issue for an older version of Fedora, also on CentOS Stream 8 works just fine.

Weird.

I think this error is related to a misconfiguration.

What I think has gone wrong is that we’ve switched over durable queues (true), and by default it will try to declare a non durable queues (false) [1].

Maybe some configurations are missing.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/5aa645b38b4c1cf08b00e687eb6c7c4b8a0211fc/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqp.py#L34

JOBLOGS ]$  grep -r 'control_exchange.*openstack'

then, we have a colliding shared control exchange, what is attempted to be configured by multiple services in different (durable/not) modes. We should make sure each service uses its dedicated control exchange

> 
> iirc, # commented means the service default is used?

Yes, if commented oslo.messaging will use default configuration [1] (here the default is `openstack`).

> then, we have a colliding shared control exchange, what is attempted to be configured by multiple services in different (durable/not) modes.

Yes I think you see this error (PRECONDITION_FAILED - inequivalent arg 'durable' for exchange 'openstack' in vhost '/': received 'true' but current is 'false') because the shared control exchange is configured  with durable (or not) at the begining and services try to apply their own config that differ from the initial configuration.

> We should make sure each service uses its dedicated control exchange

Yes, I think it could be a solution where each service declare its own dedicated control exchange with its own configuration. In other words, to avoid similar issues, I think that either each service use the same config for the shared control exchange with some kind of centralized config, or each service own its own control exchange with its own dedicated configuration.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/5aa645b38b4c1cf08b00e687eb6c7c4b8a0211fc/oslo_messaging/transport.py#L57-L62

specs/yoga/compact-wsgi-footprint.rst.message: control
Done

Can you clarify what would be running in podman?
Are you proposing running each service under python inside podman? Using the "simpleserver" implementation?
If so, note that simpleserver does not scale well and requires a lot of tuning.

That still needs further researching and PoCs, and really depends on how the podman pods would show off here. My expectation is that the pod's "pause" container should host all the needed namespaces and caches that would benefit other containers started by that podman wrapper (one per each a WSGI app) and provide the shared python interpreter context for all the app/process groups within the pod. Also, there could be a global pod or a set of the service-specific pods.
Done
WSGI?
Done
Should we discuss the "why not's" of the alternatives?

We could do this, but where it does feel like a bit like the status quo is because it was the most expeditious way of getting something working and now that we've thought it out and things it makes sense to consolidate and improve the organization of deployed services some.
I don't think we get any benefit out of moving to nginx.

Switching to nginx is a big change, requiring new puppet, etc etc. but also I suspect components don't test with nginx in their CI. uWSGI could be interesting, but requires additions to existing puppet modules, changes to existing container builds and introduces a new mechanism for web service integration. In other words, higher stability/quality risk, more work, yada yada.

uWSGI behind Apache is how the upstream devstack is setup and has a proven track record in many production environments.
This solves the memory and scale issues mod_wsgi brings.
Done
Done
also, unfortunately, uWSGI is not shipped with RHEL downstream. So switching to it would add extra maintenance burden to the deployment framework component. Fixing CVEs, building the package etc.
Done

Interesting in its different aspects and probably the most efficient in terms of resource consumption. Pooling configuration can be a little complex, one compromised configuration can affect all services, etc.. IIUC, the apache container would still be relatively "pure" and not the API packages and all of  their dependencies in the container image?
Yes, since WSGI apps should start off its dedicated container images with the needed service specific packages in it.

This is true. It would be interesting to consider the trade off - one point of vulnerability affecting multiple servers vs. the risk of making sure that *many* configurations, container builds etc. are appropriately configured for security.
Performance could decrease, depending on the design, due to the NAT required at the pod boundary (i.e. exposing the port)
Done

Also note, if you run all of the API WSGI applications under one WSGI framework and/or python instance, performance can degrade at scale due to the GIL. There is some benefit to having high-rate-of-change APIs get their own python instance.
Done

Right, that's why I proposed to use a global interpreter for all APIs only for standalone, all-in-one, single controller cases. While a default controller would only "pack" a service scoped APIs, like Nova/Placement APIs. Would be nice to bring here a full composition...
What would the actual resource count reduction look like for a default controller role with "a bunch" of stuff turned on? I think that would be a cool data point.

Something that comes to mind - and I suspect it is a non-issue are python applications that use non-native libraries (e.g. mysql, etc) and would they be impacted in anyway. Does the scheme at any point combine any form of process contexts for those third party libs where they might be multiple apps sharing memory, locks or other resources where they previously didn't. I can't see how honestly because IIUC, the various services are still running as separate containers but I thought I'd bring it up in case I'm mistaken.

We do not expect to make it all thread safe, no. For example, Nova has global state like db object that should not be shared across threads. Multiple process / singe thread MPM config should be always used I'd say. But even then there might be dragons: like can't safely reload  nova-api (and placement?) into the same python interpreter. That's because of the module level globals use to connect to DB and MQ that might have re-initialization problems.
are there any numbers on the actual amount of memory saved? How much are we talking here? I didn't see any numbers in the etherpad.

It seems the core of the proposal is writing mod_pod. I'm not a fan of this. I really don't want to bring something like that into the TripleO umbrella.

I'd really like to the #'s of the memory savings here, and weight that against the cost.
is uWSGI maintained and available in CentOS and RHEL?

Could I confirm is there any difference for performance between cases of using "all_records=yes" or not?

In the case of using "all_records=yes", if there are the large number of records in a response, it can affect the performance to respond all records at once.
In the case of not using "all_records=yes", on the other hand, the impact on the performance will be less than the first case because each page size to be responded is limited.

As a side note, in the case of using "all_records=yes", the behavior of response is not different from existing one, so there is no additional impact on the performance.
Even in the case of not using "all_records=yes", the total size of memory to be used is the same as the one in "all_records=yes" case, so there is no additional impact on the performance from existing one, too.

tempest/cmd/account_generator.py.message:
this help message is a little confusing here. "The number of accounts required can be estimated as
  CONCURRENCY x 2. " this does not say account-generator tool will *generate* two accounts for --concurrency  1 it says required account which also not so clear to me what is required means here?

Any tests can have more than two creds also like any test need project_member, project_adnmin, system_admin etc in that case generating 2 accounts will not be sufficient. We cannot make complete tempest or tempest plugins test run successfully with the default account generated by this tool.

And making concurrency=1 generating two accounts means tempest test need single creds run always in parallel and no way to run them serially. This does not sound good and is more confusing.

As tests need two creds are more cases, we can make the default value of concurrency as 2 (which is 1 currently) and if anyone wants to generate only a single account and run tests-need-single-cred serially they can set it to 1. But let this tool generate the same number of accounts what mentioned in ``-r, --concurrency CONCURRENCY``  option.

yes, it's confusing and not only the documentation but also the name of the argument - concurrency - as I understand it now, the account-generator with concurrency set to 1 will generate enough credentials for running all tempest tests serially. With concurrency set to 2 it will generate twice as many credentials (as with concurrency set to 1) so that tempest can be run with concurrency == 2 (2 workers executing tests). 

So I think we have 2 options here:
1. leave the --concurrency arg as it is and proceed with this patch
2. improve the documentation of the argument as you suggested in the other comment and rename the argument as well - let's go with something like --creds-number

and this help message can be made more clear with something like below:

* ``-r, --concurrency CONCURRENCY`` (Optional) Concurrency count
  (default: 2). The number of accounts generated will be same as
  CONCURRENCY. It can be changed to 1 if you want to run tests need single 
  creds in serial (if you try to run test need more than single creds then it
  will fail) or more than 2 if any tests need more then 2 creds. Having CONCURRENCY
  more than 1 (default is 2) means few tests need single creds will run in parallel.

Missing trailing space before the quote. This prints as:

  ...microversion.If deleting...

You can't do this. A generator is a function that uses yield instead of return. They can only be consumed once. Once consumed, they're empty. For example:

  >>> def num_sequence():
  ...     num = 0
  ...     while num < 10:
  ...         yield num
  ...         num += 1
  ... 
  >>> x = num_sequence()
  >>> len(x)
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: object of type 'generator' has no len()
  >>> len(list(x))
  10
  >>> len(list(x))
  0

You need to wrap the all to 'compute_client.services' above, rather than doing it each time.

cinder/transfer/api.py.message:
The only reason I can see to do the check here is to handle transfers that were already created before a deployment has been updated to a cinder containing this fix. 

I think it would be better to have this check in create(), where we currently do some other checks.  After all, there's nothing the acceptor can do to fix this because the group is owned by the person who created the transfer.  My suggestion is to leave this here with a TODO to remove in Z (or AA), and copy it up to the create() function where it belongs.

My initial thoughts were similar that it makes sense for create transfer but due to certain reason i made changes to accept.
The first thought in my head was create and accept are two different operations that can be performed separately in a time difference and doesn't need to happen instantly. It could be possible that the donor is planning to do some operations on the volume before removing it from the group, so donor creates a transfer, performs it's operations, removes volume from group and notifies acceptor that you can accept the transfer now. As i didn't see any issue with creating the transfer i.e. we are not changing anything in the resource or DB, it didn't feel right to me to block that operation then.
Although it doesn't make much difference if we block create or accept, the functionality will remain same for volume in groups but that's what my thoughts are on this.
Would be happy to change if my reasoning isn't valid enough.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Maybe a temporary quota reduction is less of an issue for baremetal given how often the user will want to redeploy with the exact same node.

I'm not sure I get what you're saying. If cleaning counts towards the quota, the users will end up in situation where their quota disappears for tens of minutes or even hours (in case of shredding).

This will provide another motivation for operators to disable cleaning, and I'm absolutely against doing that.

> during volume deletion in Cinder (unless you enable trash)

Does it also take from 15 minutes to many hours?
I'll propose switching this behavior based on a new nova.conf parameter
The reason we did not do it previously was IIRC because an instance in DELETING would count against the user's quota. Is it not the case?
Then I'd say that the new behavior should be optional. There may be completely opposite operation requirements here.

I think counting resources during deletion against the quota is happening in other projects as well, e.g. during volume deletion in Cinder (unless you enable trash).

I agree, though, that blocking users may increase the pressure on operators to disable cleaning. OTOH, freeing up the quota but then letting the instance creation fail without any visible explanation for the user is not much better. It depends on the deployment: if there are many free instances of the same type, the quota should be returned. If this is the only node to instantiate the user should not be given the impression his formerly used resources are available again.
Maybe a temporary quota reduction is less of an issue for baremetal given how often the user will want to redeploy with the exact same node.

Yes, absolutely. This is why I added the trash feature to Cinder to make the deletion asynchronous ... and here I am arguing in the opposite direction :) ... well, basically the same: make it flexible so you can adapt to the situation.

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message:
In comment 9 on the bug [1], the ordering of network and volume teardown is mentioned with the concern being if waiting for cleaning would hold up release of network and volume resources. This ^ is where the volume targets are removed and the vifs unplugged per comment 9.

From the compute manager perspective, as mentioned in comment 7 on the bug [2], the wait for cleaning would occur before [3] releasing resources in neutron [4] and cinder [5] and also before the instance record is deleted [6]. And quota for the respective resources won't be released until after cleaning is finished.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1884217/comments/9
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1884217/comments/7
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d5b6412ef52b1e5ad797a49850c9c6701b0405db/nova/compute/manager.py#L2903
[4] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d5b6412ef52b1e5ad797a49850c9c6701b0405db/nova/compute/manager.py#L2920
[5] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d5b6412ef52b1e5ad797a49850c9c6701b0405db/nova/compute/manager.py#L2923-L2936
[6] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d5b6412ef52b1e5ad797a49850c9c6701b0405db/nova/compute/manager.py#L3057

AFAICT if the node never changes to AVAILABLE or CLEANFAIL, this will loop indefinitely and hold up the nova-compute delete path indefinitely. I understand that cleaning can take quite a long time, but maybe a configurable timeout for this retry should be added? If for some reason we don't want to put a timeout here, I think we should add a note or warning to the config option help text to say that the wait for cleaning will never timeout.

This tells me nothing how the error of having the wrong commit IDs listed in TIS_BASE_SRCREV is causing the release number to be erratic. What is the link? Document this in the commit log.

"The TIS_BASE_SRCREV were not updated after moving to 5.10.74 this caused the <explaing here> which resulted in erratic release numbers. By fixing the TIS_BASE_SRCREV the <explain here> works as expected again, which allows release number generation to return to proper incrementing"

Please do a better job of explaining the issue and fix in the commit logs.

I agree.  A better explanation is needed in the commit test.

I think I know the general story...

At it's heart, the old TIS_BASE_SRCREV was so far from the checkout sha that the shallow clone (used in our repo manifest) drops a lot of the history that connects the two sha's, making the commit count between the two incorrect.

How much history gets dropped seems a bit erratic, depending on when the repo gets updated.
Ack

while this should result in a predictable tis release number, it also causes the release number to go backwards.  It should only increase.  

We'll need to temporarily add an offset to ensure it does not decrease.   e.g.

TIS_PATCH_VER=GITREVCOUNT+PKG_GITREVCOUNT+123

not sure what exact value is required.

build out the following rpms without the fix.  so I set offset 1800 for std, 1200 for rt.
/localdisk/loadbuild/jma1/stx-master-0104/rt/rpmbuild/SRPMS/kernel-rt-5.10.74-200.1131.tis.rt.el7.src.rpm

/localdisk/loadbuild/jma1/stx-master-0104/std/rpmbuild/RPMS/kernel-5.10.74-200.1807.tis.el7.x86_64.rpm

So I'm confused.  If the versions you list are built without your fix commit, why would you add only 1800 for std when the built version number is 1807?  If I was doing this, I'd just add 2000 to both rt and std.  It then becomes clear and obvious if a built package is pre or post your fix.

Hi Jiping,

I am not Scott, but you can determine the required package revision offset as follows:

* Build the kernel-rt SRPM without any patches, on the latest StarlingX baseline, and record the kernel-rt SRPM package's release number. Let's *say/assume* that the kernel-rt package's release number is now 2000.

* Now, build the kernel-rt SRPM with your patch, but *without* +100. Record the release number. Let's assume that the release number is 101.

* We want to make the new release number 2001, so in the build_srpm.data file add an additional offset of +1900 to the variable TIS_PATCH_VER.

* Now re-build the kernel-rt SRPM, and confirm that the release number is 2001.

* Repeat the same procedure for the standard kernel (the "kernel" package).

Hope this helps!

I wouldn't worry about leaving a gap.  Say the old build produces a number of 8678.  I would just add 9000 to TIS_PATCH_VER and go from there without trying to produce 8679.  Next time the kernel is moved forward don't forget to remove the +9000.

std/rpmbuild/RPMS/kernel-5.10.74-200.121.tis.el7.x86_64.rpm

If I did not add offset 100.  build out kernel rpms.

rt/rpmbuild/RPMS/kernel-rt-5.10.74-200.17.tis.rt.el7.x86_64.rpm
std/rpmbuild/RPMS/kernel-5.10.74-200.21.tis.el7.x86_64.rpm
